children.subject:
I somewhat disagree with the other student, but I also haven’t taken 186. I personally am not super interested in databases, but depending on what you want to do it could be important. 

Data 100 is indeed less theoretical and more practical (numpy, pandas, matplotlib, sklearn, etc.). I had learned most of the theory from other EE/CS classes. However, the practical skills you learn from the homework and projects were invaluable for me during my summer internships (Computer Vision/Deep Learning startup) and as a research assistant in an EECS lab. You learn the tools and the workflows that most machine learning practitioners use daily. If you think you can teach learn them yourself that’s also fine, but at least for me it’s always different to take a class and really dive in. 

I know nothing about IEOR but 170 + D100 + a light tech is a pretty decent workload imo.

history.content:
Is this workload manageable? I plan on doing a breadth at a community college online, which should just be an additional 6 hours tops per week. I know 170 will have tough problem sets. IEOR 185 is something out of my own interest, since IEOR 135 doesn't look offered for the  fall anymore. I'm split between CS W186 and Data 100. I know both are great courses, but which would be more useful for software engineering internships?

I've heard mixed things about Data 100, but  from the general jist of things, Data 100 seems like a class on using tools and how to use those tools on data, while 186 is literally all about databases and how they work. 186 seems more foundational and harder to "self-learn" so I'm leaning towards that. Any thoughts?
history.subject: CS 170 + IEOR 185 + CS W186/ Data 100 + Breadth
